This movie is nothing short of a dark, gritty masterpiece. I may be bias, as the Apartheid era is an area I've always felt for South Africans. The problems they have are immense due to this time in history and revisiting those days allows us to see how many issues lie deep with in their present day children.

Movie about two Australian girls--Debbie (Nell Schofield) and Sue (Sue Knight)--and what happens when they become girlfriends of two surly bikers--Casey (John-Paul Tremblay) and his mate Dean (Ben McCrae). Their lives are almost a mirror image of one another's, with the boys slow motion versions of the girls, but nobody really realises this at first.

I had mixed feelings for "Les Valseuses" (1974) written and directed by Bertrand Blier when I started watching it but I ended up loving it. Nothing like a traumatic stress from an unreal situation to your family and friends. The film is full of unexpected hilarious moments parodying itself and this, with any luck, allows the spectator to get away enough from certain petulancies.
